subclassFeature.name: Magnetism
entries: Most sorcerers born with powers over magnetism are born during great cosmic alignments, or in gravitational anomalies, and have a great affinity for metals and ores. Able to use their powers to influence and bend such metals as well as the forces of magnetism to their whims.

You could be a sorcerer born with an innate ferrokinetic sorcery that grants you mastery over the raw energies and materials of the universe by generating and controlling magnetic fields. Perhaps your powers manifested after the stars aligned in an ancient formation over your birthplace. Maybe they were granted to you by a mysterious patron or by a set of experiments that may have gone wrong. Whatever the case, it is undeniable that your control and mastery over metals is undeniable.

However your sorcery came to be, all magnetism sorcerers share one trait. This being that their eyes chrome over when they use their magic. You may roll or choose from the following table to determine what metal this is, or you may perhaps choose your own type of metal. The choice is yours.

subclassFeature.name: Alloy Spells
entries: As a Magnetism Sorcerer, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Alloy Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These are not the only magnetism spells that can be learned by you, but these are the ones that are innately known by you as you gain more experience.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you have become able to bend sets of metallic armor to your will, allowing them to perfectly suit you. You are proficient with light armor, medium armor, and shields so long as the armor or shield is made of metal. Your metal armor or shield may also serve as your spell casting focus for sorcerer spells while you are wearing it.

subclassFeature.name: Reshape Metal
entries: Also at 1st level, you can use your ferrous powers to reshape a non-magical metal object. The object must be within ten feet of you and weigh no more than 5 lbs per sorcerer level you possess. This process takes one action, and cannot be used on objects that are being worn or carried by another creature.

The only limit is your imagination: for example, a dagger’s blade could be reshaped into a crude grappling hook, the hinge of a door could be removed, or the head of a spear could be warped beyond recognition.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Propulsion
entries: At 6th level, you’ve learned to use the magnetic objects around you to your fullest advantage. Propelling them with such force that they can completely, and utterly decimate your foes.

You may target an object you can see within 60 feet of you as an action, spend sorcery points depending on the object or creature’s size indicated by the list below to throw them violently at an object or creature within 60 feet of you.

Make a ranged spell attack roll against the object or creature you are targeting. On a successful hit, the target takes an amount of damage depending on the size of the object or creature thrown. All damage will be bludgeoning, slashing, or piercing damage depending on the improvised weapon used. If an object is thrown, both the object and the target take the damage. The object being thrown takes the damage rolled, even if the attack misses.

subclassFeature.name: Electromagnetic Field
entries: Also at 6th level, you’ve started to realize the true potentials of the power of magnetism, able to summon electromagnetic force fields to protect you from harm. As a reaction to taking damage, you can spend two sorcery points to negate the damage entirely. In addition, you gain temporary hit points equal to your charisma modifier as the force field faintly lingers.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Manipulator
entries: At 14th level, your control over the magnetic properties in your body and other metallic objects increases, granting you a hover speed equal to your movement speed.

Also, as an action, on your turn you can target a single metal object or metal creature within 120 feet of you that weighs up to a number of pounds equal to your Sorcerer level x 100 and move them up to 30 feet in any direction. If you target an unwilling creature, that creature must succeed a Strength saving throw to be unaffected. If you are targeting an object that is being worn or carried the creature can make a Strength saving throw to not have the object move, this can be failed voluntarily.
You exert fine control on objects with these magnetic abilities, such as being able to manipulate a simple tool, open a door, or move a Goliath in metal plate.
In addition, your Magnetic Propulsion feature can now target creatures made of metal or wearing metal armor. An unwilling creature may make a Strength saving throw to be unaffected.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Prison
entries: At 18th level, you’ve truly mastered your powers of magnetism. As an action, by expending five sorcery points, you can call upon whatever metal surrounds you, even if that metal is but mere minerals beneath the earth. Any creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained within their metal binds for 1 minute, and take {@damage 3d10} magical bludgeoning damage as they’re crushed, half damage on a successful save. A creature may repeat the save at the end of their turns, ending the effect on a successful save.

In addition, when you levitate an object with your Magnetic Manipulator feature, you may expend sorcery points to increase the amount of weight you can lift. For every sorcery point you expend, you can lift an additional five hundred pounds.
